This reminded me of the Saturdays from last year when Joel Fagliano was filling in as editor. It wasn‚Äôt bad at all, in fact I rather liked this one. It just felt more contemporary. Which is probably why I did well.

TIL: 1) An adult cheetah weighs between 75 and 140 LBS. 2) The actor who played PEETA in "The Hunger Games" is named JOSH Hutcherson. (PEETA was a gimme but I didn't know the actor's name.) 3) The names of a couple of INCAN gods. 4) "CODA" won Best Picture. I love that movie but had no idea it had won the big prize. (The music group I volunteer with for developmentally-disabled adults is signing to "Both Sides Now" at our concert in two weeks.) 5) There's a candy called SLO Poke. 6) There's a mathematical process called a RANDOM WALK. I'm just so tickled that after doing several puzzles every day since last August, I rarely have to look anything up anymore. Everything eventually comes together through crosses and logic, kind of like a Polaroid picture, and this puzzle was no exception. Zero lookups. Feels like magical! (Okay, I now that I mentioned Polaroid, I've got this ear worm in my head! https://youtu.be/PWgvGjAhvIw?si=HuKUZ5hLCpToqair)

It took me an embarrassingly long time to enter "random" instead of looking for a synonym for "drunkard".

I love solo Rafa puzzles. There's always, for me, a perfect balance of breeziness, but with lots of cleverness, and resistance, but without hair-pulling. A favorite misdirect prize goes to [House in Milan] ARMANI. Well, it was a misdirect in my book because I read "Milano" and of course wanted "casa," the Italian word for "house". ARMANI came to me with a big aha ‚Äì and an extra aha, even if wrong, never hurt anyone. My favorite *real* misdirect prize goes to TROJAN WAR. Brilliant. Thank you, Rafa. You are a constructing force to be reckoned with! I had to look up JOSH and BURRO to get some crosses to unlock the NW quadrant of the grid, but other than that I needed no outside help. 

Some of the clues were quite nice, some were not. PRIORI doesn't mean "before" in Latin: "prius" means "earlier" (as in, an earlier [one]), and "priori" is one of its forms in declension. But I'm not going to get through with this to Americans, or English speakers in general, am I? The last time I tried I got nowhere. In languages with declension, a name of a thing, place, person or concept is only ever given in the nominative case: a Polish crossword puzzle only ever features words in the nominative case. For example, Warsaw is Warszawa in the nominative. The name looks different in other cases, e.g., in the vocative it's "Warszawo!" The name of the city in Polish is Warszawa, not Warszawo. And this is where I loose touch with people whose language does not involve declension: "Warszawo!" does not mean Warsaw in Polish. Only "Warszawa" does. Ditto prius and priori.
Clocked my fastest Saturday solve at 17m. Was it me or the puzzle? Don‚Äôt tell me‚Ä¶

At the 10 minute mark, this was going to be my fastest Saturday by miles. All that was left was to crack the NE, and given the crosses I already had, that would take a minute or two at most!

Final time: 27 minutes. I don‚Äôt know if my critical faculties suddenly shut down, or if my total lack of sports knowledge just made me incapable of seeing NBA FINALS, or if AY CARUMBA is just not a term my brain can parse with even a single letter missing, but wow. Never have I spent so long on such a tiny part of a puzzle when the rest came so easily.

None of this is to blame the constructor in any way. It was fun and fair, and deep down I know I‚Äôd rather beat my head a little on a Saturday then get some personal best I‚Äôll spend every other Saturday chasing in vain.

Just kind of surprised. Dont' know if anyone else is interested in stuff like that, but... whatever.

Regarding RANDOM WALK, the processes do not need to be unpredictable. It really depends on how you calibrate the model. For example, you can predict interest rates, which are unknown but not necessarily unpredictable. 

Truly unpredictable events are called BLACK SWANS and by definition cannot be foreseen or predicted using a mathematical model. 

You can certainly look at tail events as extreme cases but again they can be imagined. For example, the effect of a pandemic with 5 times the mortality of COVID can be determined. A black swan event is not a tail event because it is unfathomable.

@Francis 

In Polish your name would be Franciszek. The female version of the name, Frances, is Franciszka. 

Now...

A car of yours, say, a Mercedes, would be "Mercedes Franciszka" (declension changes the form of your name in the genitive case. See that it becomes the same as the nominative of the Polish Frances?). If you were in a relationship with the domina Frances (Franciszka) you would be "Franciszek Franciszki" (Frances's Francis, because Franciszki is the genitive of Franciszka).

Knowing this, can you appreciate that it only makes sense to present words in languages recognizing declension in the nominative case? Your name in Polish is Franciszek, not Franciszka, even though the genitive of Franciszek is... Franciszka. Nominative trumps all other cases when giving the name of something.

BTW, English may not have declension, but the thing you do with 's for possessing something is similar. You *will* agree "Francis's" is not your name, even though "Francis's car" is a thing, right?

@Andrzej 

So many thoughts about your comment, Andrzej!

First, the Latin:  PRIORI is the dative singular of prius, which is a noun that means "earlier times".  It's a good question whether a clue that asks for the "Latin [word] for 'before'" can be answered with any case of the desired word.  However, as Steve L. would point out, technically every declension of prius has the same basic meaning as it does in the nominative.

Most people in the U.S. learn grammar (including declension and conjugation) when they learn a foreign language.  Grammar in their native tongue comes naturally.  I suspect that this is true not only of Americans.

Fewer Americans study foreign language than do people in other (educated) countries, and many Americans expect "foreigners" (i.e. non-Americans) to speak (American) English, whether they are at home or abroad.  This makes me sad.

But many Americans do know foreign languages. Some have even studied Latin!

@The X-Phile 

"technically every declension of prius has the same basic meaning as it does in the nominative."

But that's exactly not the case! The root is the same but the meaning is completely different. Samoch√≥d Andrzeja means Andrzej's car. Samoch√≥d Andrzej means... A car called Andrzej. The meaning of the whole sentence changes completely depending on the case of the name being subjected to declension.

And, again, and I can't stress this enough, something's name in a language with declension is only its nominative version. No, a form in any case will simply not do. Warsaw in Polish is Warszawa, and not Warszawy, Warszawie, WarszawƒÖ or Warszawo! This is not up for discussion if you're enquiring about the meaning of the word/name in its native tongue, like today's before "in Latin" did.

@Nick 

The clue literally asked us for the meaning of before IN LATIN. Not in an American's idea of what Latin may be (and is not).

@Andrzej 
And ‚Äúprior‚Äù (singular masculine or feminine nominative) ‚Äúprius‚Äù (singular neuter nominative), and ‚Äúpriori‚Äù (singular masculine, feminine, or neuter ablative) are all possible translations of the English word ‚Äúbefore‚Äù into Latin; the clue indicates nothing about where in a sentence or phrase the word is supposed to come.

If you elect to ignore everything I wrote above, fine. I give up. You're better at languages with declension than I am, sorry for bothering you with my ignorance. Andrzejowi signing out.

@Barry Ancona 

Yes, sorry for being too vague. 

The Games apps are for mobile devices: phones and tablets. And I don't use them, so I usually forget to make that distinction! The NYT Games are also accessible via a browser on those mobile devices.

On a computer, the only access is via a browser -- also known as a web browser -- such as when you solve in the archive. 

Each of these form factors is served a different layout in what is sometimes called "responsive design", meaning elements are rearranged to fit the screen size and orientation. Simplistically, these are identified as "mobile" or "phone"; "tablet"; and "desktop", though that last could be either a laptop or a larger computer with a standalone monitor. 

So for example, when I open the Games main page on my phone, boxes with access to the Crossword and Mini display side by side at the top, with just a simple button below linking to the Wordplay column. (The other games, ads, stats, archive, etc. all display farther down the page.) Once you're in the puzzle, there is no direct access to Wordplay -- it's like as you described, having to open it on another page.

On the larger computer screen, however, the crossword grid is laid out on the left and the clues on the right; Wordplay access is immediately below the grid, displayed (as article links are throughout the NYT website) with a thumbnail image + headline. Thus the problem.
